concepts.name: Project Gutenberg
concepts.description: A project to create and distribute free eBooks.

concepts.name: License
concepts.description: The Project Gutenberg License, governing the use and distribution of eBooks.

concepts.name: Author
concepts.description: The writer of the book, in this case Jane Austen.

concepts.name: Pride and Prejudice
concepts.description: The title of the eBook, a novel by Jane Austen.

concepts.name: Copyright
concepts.description: Legal protection of the work, or lack thereof.

concepts.name: United States
concepts.description: The primary location where Project Gutenberg operates.

concepts.name: Character
concepts.description: A person or entity in the novel.

concepts.name: Plot
concepts.description: The sequence of events in the novel.

concepts.name: Themes
concepts.description: Underlying ideas or messages in the novel, such as pride, prejudice, love, and social class.

concepts.name: Elizabeth Bennet
concepts.description: The heroine of Pride and Prejudice.

concepts.name: Mr. Darcy
concepts.description: The hero of Pride and Prejudice.

concepts.name: Jane Austen
concepts.description: The author of Pride and Prejudice.

concepts.name: Goldwin Smith
concepts.description: A critic who observed the perfection and narrowness of Austen's field.

concepts.name: Mr. Collins
concepts.description: A pompous and obsequious clergyman in Pride and Prejudice.

relationships.description: eBooks are distributed by Project Gutenberg.
Use of eBooks is governed by the Project Gutenberg License.
Pride and Prejudice was written by Jane Austen.
Pride and Prejudice is in the public domain in the United States.
Project Gutenberg operates primarily in the United States.
Pride and Prejudice contains various characters.
Pride and Prejudice has a plot.
Pride and Prejudice explores themes such as pride and prejudice.
Elizabeth Bennet is a character in Pride and Prejudice.
Mr. Darcy is a character in Pride and Prejudice.
Jane Austen is the author of Pride and Prejudice.
Pride and Prejudice was analyzed by Goldwin Smith.
